title: 2025 review of the United Nations peacebuilding architecture

General Assembly 
Distr.: Limited 
20 November 2025 
Original: English

Eightieth session 
Agenda item 62 
Peacebuilding and sustaining peace 
 
 
 
 
 
Draft resolution submitted by the President of the General Assembly 
 
 
 
 2025 review of the United Nations peacebuilding architecture 
 
 
 
The General Assembly, 
 
Guided by the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations, and 
renewing its commitment to international cooperation, 
 
Recalling the relevant provisions adopted at the Summit of the Future on 22 and 
23 September 2024, and reaffirming all General Assembly and Security Council 
resolutions and statements by the President of the Security Council on peacebuilding 
and sustaining peace,1 
 
Reaffirming that development, peace and security and human rights are 
interlinked and mutually reinforcing, 
 
Reaffirming its deep concern at the high human cost and suffering caused by 
armed conflicts, and expressing grave alarm about the significant number of 
simultaneous security and humanitarian crises that the world currently faces, and the 
strain that this places on the resources of the United Nations system, 
 
Recognizing that investing in conflict prevention is a highly cost-effective 
solution and results in saving lives, stabilizing economies and reducing the need for 
costly military responses, 
 
Recognizing also the vital role of the United Nations in preventing conflicts, in 
assisting parties to conflicts to end hostilities and emerge towards recovery, 
reconstruction and development and in mobilizing sustained international attention 
and assistance, 
 
Recognizing further that conflict prevention should be nationally led and owned, 
and reaffirming that Member States bear the primary responsibility for preventing 
conflict and building peace and for addressing the root causes of violence and conflict 
in their countries, and that national efforts to build and sustain peace contribute to the 
maintenance of international peace and security,

Recalling that peacebuilding is an inherently political process aimed at 
preventing the outbreak, escalation, recurrence or continuation of conflict, and further 
recognizing that peacebuilding encompasses a wide range of political, development, 
and human rights programmes and mechanisms, 
 
Recognizing the importance of ensuring impact of United Nations system-wide 
activities, including planning and joint analysis, in support of peacebuilding and 
sustaining peace efforts, and bearing in mind in this regard the role of the three core 
components of the United Nations peacebuilding architecture in leveraging the entire 
United Nations system and the importance of greater synergies between them, while 
reiterating in this regard the important role that effective and responsive leadership in 
the United Nations in the field can play in peacebuilding and sustaining peace, 
 
Recognizing also the contribution of peace operations in efforts to advance 
peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and mindful of the ongoing review of the 
Secretary-General on the future of all forms of United Nations peace operations, 
 
Reaffirming the primary responsibility of national Governments and authorities 
in identifying, driving and directing priorities, strategies and activities for 
peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and emphasizing the importance of ensuring that 
the needs of all segments of society are taken into account, while reiterating the 
importance of partnerships with relevant stakeholders, including regional and 
subregional organizations, international financial institutions, civil society 
organizations, local peacebuilding stakeholders and, where relevant, the private 
sector, in supporting national peacebuilding priorities, 
 
Reaffirming also, in the context of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the adoption 
of Security Council resolution 1325 (2000) on 31 October 2000, the important role of 
women in peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and recognizing that the full, equal, 
meaningful and safe participation of women at all decision-making levels in efforts 
to prevent, resolve and rebuild from conflict is important to achieve durable solutions 
and long-term stability, 
 
Reaffirming further, in the context of the tenth anniversary of the adoption of 
Security Council resolution 2250 (2015) on 9 December 2015, that the full, effective, 
safe and meaningful participation of youth is critical to maintain and promote 
international peace and security through peacebuilding and sustaining peace efforts, 
 
Expressing the need for increased visibility and awareness of United Nations 
peacebuilding and sustaining peace activities, particularly where it contributes to 
demonstrating impact and mobilizing support, 
 
Taking note of the report of the Secretary-General on peacebuilding and sustaining 
peace of 25 November 20242 and the inputs for the 2025 review of the peacebuilding 
architecture of the Peacebuilding Commission through its letter dated 13 November 
20243 and the former Chairs of the Peacebuilding Commission through their letter dated 
12 May 2025, and inputs from thematic and regional consultations, and encouraging 
relevant United Nations bodies and organs, including the Peacebuilding Commission, 
to consider the inputs further, and further acknowledging the inputs from the group of 
independent eminent persons through its letter dated 21 November 2024,4 
 
Affirming that the 2025 review of the peacebuilding architecture is aimed at 
further enhancing the implementation and impact of peacebuilding activities at the 
field level,

Peacebuilding Commission 
 
 
1. 
Reaffirms all relevant resolutions relating to the mandate of the 
Peacebuilding Commission, and, mindful of the important role of the Commission, 
also reaffirms the need to strengthen its fulfilment by: 
 
(a) 
Requesting the Peacebuilding Commission to establish a detailed, 
predictable and flexible annual programme of work reflecting, inter alia, its country-
specific, regional and thematic issues, while also taking into consideration the 
programmes of work of the General Assembly, the Security Council and the Economic 
and Social Council, as appropriate; 
 
(b) 
Requesting the Peacebuilding Commission, in line with its mandate, to 
serve as a platform to support Member States, upon their request, to strengthen their 
national peacebuilding and sustaining peace efforts by: 
 
(i) 
Assisting Member States in building their national capacities to promote, 
develop, where they do not exist, and implement their voluntary and nationally 
owned prevention and peacebuilding strategies, efforts and other related 
frameworks in accordance with their national priorities and needs, including by 
sharing good practices and lessons learned; 
 
(ii) Inviting international financial institutions and regional development 
banks to engage in relevant country-specific discussions, upon request by the 
country concerned, including on nationally led and owned prevention and 
peacebuilding strategies, priorities and other related frameworks and, where 
appropriate and in line with their governance arrangements, to consider 
providing additional resources in support of their implementation; 
 
(c) 
Taking note of the decision of the Security Council to consider, where 
appropriate and on a case-by-case basis, referring countries transitioning off its 
agenda, at their request and with their consent, to the Peacebuilding Commission, 
with due respect for national ownership and mindful of the benefits of sustained 
engagement with the Commission; 
 
(d) 
Requesting the Peacebuilding Commission to strengthen its impact 
through regular follow-up, monitoring and assessment of the implementation of its 
outcomes, and diversified modalities of engagement with relevant stakeholders; 
 
(e) 
Requesting the Peacebuilding Commission to continue serving as a 
platform to convene all relevant actors, and gather analysis and expertise, including 
by leveraging information related to peacebuilding impact, with a view to advocating 
for developing and sharing good practices in peacebuilding and promoting system-
wide coordination; 
 
(f) 
Requesting the Peacebuilding Commission to continue monitoring the 
implementation of its existing strategies and action plans, including through their 
regular assessments, to advance the women and peace and security and youth, peace 
and security agendas, with a view to supporting the full, equal, meaningful and safe 
participation of women, and promoting the full, effective, safe and meaningful 
participation of youth in peacebuilding and sustaining peace; 
 
(g) 
Requesting the Peacebuilding Commission to continue reviewing its 
working methods and practices, with a view to enhancing the efficiency in delivering 
on its mandates, and its impact in support of peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and 
also requesting the Commission to report back in the context of its annual report; 
 
(h) 
Reaffirming the practice that, in the use of conference rooms, priority must 
be given to meetings of Member States, and in this regard requests the Secretariat to 
explore options, within existing resources, to regularly provide venues and

4/7 
 
conference services to the Peacebuilding Commission, including by providing it with 
priority access to rooms with full United Nations membership capacity for its 
ambassadorial-level meetings, without prejudice to the scheduling requirements of 
the Charter bodies; 
 
(i) 
Requesting the Department of Global Communications of the Secretariat, 
in partnership with the Peacebuilding Support Office, and within existing resources, 
to support the Peacebuilding Commission in providing regular coverage and 
increasing the visibility of its activities in order to attract more attention from the 
media and the public; 
 
2. 
Recognizes the importance of further enhancing the advisory role of the 
Peacebuilding Commission, and in this regard: 
 
(a) 
Decides, where appropriate and through its relevant agenda items, and 
with a view to further strengthening its engagement with the Peacebuilding 
Commission, to consider seeking strategic and context-specific advice from the 
Peacebuilding Commission, including, where relevant, through the convening of joint 
debates and the provision by the Commission of advice and remarks to the General 
Assembly, and through more regular, demand-driven interactions between the 
Commission and the Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations; 
 
(b) 
May consider, when seeking the advice of the Peacebuilding Commission, 
diverse formats of engagement, as appropriate, including briefings, written 
submissions, informal interactive dialogues and other informal consultations; 
 
(c) 
Requests the Peacebuilding Commission to utilize its convening role to 
gather contributions from a broad range of stakeholders that may be used in the 
preparation of its advice, so as to provide recommendations and information to 
improve their coordination, to develop and share good practices in peacebuilding, and 
in this regard further requests the United Nations leadership in countries considered 
by the Commission to regularly brief the Commission, as appropriate, on the 
peacebuilding components of relevant mandates and activities; 
 
(d) 
Takes note of the intention of the Security Council to encourage stronger 
cooperation with the Peacebuilding Commission, including through more specific 
requests, early consultations and the provision of timely advice, including with the 
longer-term perspective required for peacebuilding and sustaining peace being 
reflected in the formation, review and drawdown of peace operations mandates, as 
well as planning and early coordination preceding transition processes; 
 
3. 
Encourages 
improved 
cooperation 
between 
the 
Peacebuilding 
Commission and the Economic and Social Council, in accordance with their 
respective mandates, taking into account the oversight role of the Council for 
operational activities for development and humanitarian assistance and its overall 
coordination of the United Nations development system, including through the 
agencies, funds and programmes, in support of coordination and coherence in 
peacebuilding and sustaining peace efforts with a view to maximizing impact on the 
ground; 
 
4. 
Calls for the Peacebuilding Commission to serve as a platform to enhance 
United Nations system-wide coherence in support of peacebuilding and sustaining 
peace, including by encouraging input to its deliberations from across the United 
Nations system; 
 
5. 
Encourages United Nations country teams, under the leadership and 
coordination of resident coordinators, to improve inter-agency coordination and 
synergy, consistent with their respective mandates, and to contribute to the efforts of 
the Peacebuilding Commission in peacebuilding and sustaining peace, addressing 

A/80/L.15
 
5/7
25-18981 
 
risks for development programming and fostering resilience, at the request of host 
countries and in accordance with their national ownership, plans and priorities, and 
further requests that resident coordinators be provided with necessary capacities and 
training to support these priorities, within existing resources; 
 
6. 
Requests the Secretary-General to further encourage systematic and 
strategic collaboration with international financial institutions at the country level, 
leveraging comparative advantages, including by requesting resident coordinators to 
make systematic use of partnership tools, as appropriate, to support joint analysis, 
assessment, coordination and programming efforts, upon request of the national 
Governments and authorities of the countries concerned, and also requests the 
Secretary-General to continue updating the Peacebuilding Commission on this 
collaboration through existing modalities; 
 
7. 
Encourages the Peacebuilding Commission, in full respect of national 
ownership, to continue mobilizing resources and technical expertise for national 
peacebuilding priorities, such as in relation to development, human rights, justice, 
disarmament, demobilization and reintegration and security sector reform, to support 
national efforts to build and strengthen the capacities of inclusive, resilient and 
accountable national institutions and enhance good governance; 
 
8. 
Also encourages the Peacebuilding Commission to further strengthen its 
strategic and operational partnerships with international financial institutions to 
advance peacebuilding and sustaining peace efforts, including by establishing, within 
existing resources, an annual strategic dialogue with international financial 
institutions, and holding informal exchanges between the Commission and the 
executive boards of those institutions; 
 
9. 
Welcomes the existing collaboration of the Peacebuilding Commission 
with regional and subregional organizations, and encourages the Commission to 
explore opportunities, within existing resources, for a more systematic engagement 
with other relevant regional and subregional organizations where such engagement 
supports nationally identified peacebuilding priorities; 
 
10. Encourages the Peacebuilding Commission to further strengthen its 
relationship with the African Union with a view to supporting the pillars of the 
African Union Post-Conflict, Reconstruction and Development policy for its 
implementation, and in this regard requests the Peacebuilding Support Office to 
further strengthen its cooperation with the African Union Centre for Post-Conflict 
Reconstruction 
and 
Development for implementing the 
memorandum of 
understanding on United Nations-African Union partnership in peacebuilding of 
2017, and also encourages the Commission to further enhance its strategic partnership 
with the African Union Peace and Security Council and to create a mechanism, within 
existing resources, to follow up on the implementation of relevant recommendations 
that emanate from their annual joint consultative meetings; 
 
11. 
Also encourages the Peacebuilding Commission to further consult with 
relevant civil society organizations, especially local peacebuilders, grass-roots 
organizations, and women-led and youth-led organizations from countries considered 
by the Commission; 
 
12. Decides to establish, within existing resources, an annual “peacebuilding 
week” in June, timed around the commemoration of the inaugural meeting of the 
Commission, aimed at raising awareness of the peacebuilding and sustaining peace 
efforts of the United Nations among a wide and inclusive group of stakeholders, 
fostering inclusive dialogue on peacebuilding approaches and promoting the sharing 
of good practices in peacebuilding and sustaining peace;

Peacebuilding financing 
 
 
13. Calls for the full implementation of relevant resolutions on financing for 
peacebuilding; 
 
14. Encourages the Peacebuilding Commission to maintain a regular and 
strategic dialogue with the Peacebuilding Fund, and continue its engagement with the 
Advisory Group of the Fund to support improved strategic alignment and 
information-sharing; 
 
15. Encourages countries receiving support from the Peacebuilding Fund to 
share with the Peacebuilding Commission their national peacebuilding priorities, 
challenges and lessons learned as well as key outcomes and results of activities 
financed through the Fund, and requests the Secretary-General to reflect this 
information in the existing reporting on the Fund, where relevant; 
 
16. Encourages the Secretary-General to consider how the Peacebuilding 
Fund can further enhance its support to conflict-affected countries preparing for or 
undergoing transitions from peace operations, in accordance with their national 
priorities; 
 
17. Also encourages the Secretary-General to utilize the Peacebuilding Fund 
to support countries, upon their request, to work in coordination with relevant 
stakeholders, on the basis of the principles of national leadership and ownership, to 
advance greater coherence in peacebuilding, including in support of voluntary 
national prevention and peacebuilding strategies and approaches to sustain peace; 
 
18. Encourages the Peacebuilding Commission, in coordination with the 
Peacebuilding Fund and the Peacebuilding Support Office, to engage with the private 
sector to promote investments with a view to supporting the national peacebuilding 
priorities and activities in conflict-affected countries considered by the Commission; 
 
19. Requests the Secretary-General to update, within existing modalities, the 
Peacebuilding Commission and inform its discussions on progress made and 
forthcoming opportunities with respect to innovative finance for peacebuilding, 
including recommendations for further action; 
 
20. Requests the Peacebuilding Support Office to provide annual updates, 
within existing modalities, on progress in advancing United Nations partnership with 
international financial institutions, including regional development banks and other 
relevant financing partners, including examples of innovation and good practice and 
the catalytic effect of the Peacebuilding Fund; 
 
21. Encourages the Peacebuilding Commission, recalling its mandate to bring 
together all relevant actors to marshal resources, to track the amount of resources it 
mobilizes in support of countries under its consideration and have the Chair provide 
an update thereon, within existing resources; 
 
22. Encourages continued investment by Member States in initiatives that 
promote the full, equal, meaningful and safe participation and leadership of women 
in peacebuilding, including through support for the social, economic and political 
empowerment of women; 
 
23. Urges efforts to address existing financing gaps for youth-led initiatives 
and youth organizations to ensure the full, effective and meaningful participation of 
youth in the design, monitoring and implementation of peacebuilding efforts at all 
levels, and encourages all financing stakeholders to increase coordination and 
collaboration with youth on financing national priorities;

Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs/Peacebuilding Support Office 
 
 
24. Encourages the Peacebuilding Support Office to further enhance internal 
cooperation and coordination and continue using its existing coordination 
mechanisms to gather timely and relevant contributions from relevant actors within 
and outside the United Nations, to support the thematic and geographic activities of 
the Peacebuilding Commission in a timely, focused and relevant manner; 
 
25. Encourages the Secretary-General to more systematically include data and 
analysis in his reporting on peacebuilding and sustaining peace, and in this regard 
further encourages the Secretary-General to leverage the expertise of the 
Peacebuilding Support Office on measuring impact for an evidence-based and more 
cohesive approach to peacebuilding impact, drawing on capabilities from across the 
system to track and report on peacebuilding impact at the country and regional levels 
more effectively, with the support of all relevant national stakeholders, and to update, 
as appropriate, the Peacebuilding Commission, within existing resources; 
 
26. Recognizes the important role of the Peacebuilding Support Office with its 
intergovernmental, strategy and partnerships, and financing expertise, and efforts to 
leverage the entire United Nations system and key partners, in support of the 
Peacebuilding Commission and of Member States’ national peacebuilding needs and 
objectives, bearing in mind the context of ongoing reforms of the United Nations, and 
encourages Member States to strengthen the capacities of the Peacebuilding Support 
Office, within existing resources, or through voluntary funding; 
 
27. Requests the Secretary-General to assess how ongoing reforms of the 
United Nations in the context of the UN80 Initiative, in line with relevant General 
Assembly resolutions, can further enhance cooperation among relevant United 
Nations system entities to deliver more coordinated, coherent, integrated and 
impactful peacebuilding efforts at the country level, including by improving 
leadership, accountability and capacity for peacebuilding and sustaining peace; 
 
28. Requests the Peacebuilding Commission to include in its annual report 
information on progress in implementing relevant provisions of the present resolution 
ahead of the next review; 
 
29. Reiterates its request to the Secretary-General to continue to present a 
report every two years following this review, on the ongoing implementation of the 
resolutions on peacebuilding and sustaining peace, with due attention to the impact 
of relevant reforms on the performance of the United Nations system in advancing 
the implementation of the resolutions on peacebuilding and sustaining peace; 
 
30. Calls for a further comprehensive review of United Nations peacebuilding 
in 2030.
